trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing app (Windows Store JavaScript) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing app (Windows Store JavaScript) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to get started using Mobile Services to leverage data in your Windows Store JavaScript app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to get started using Mobile Services to leverage data in your Windows Store JavaScript app.

trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing app
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services to leverage data in a Windows Store app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services to leverage data in a Windows Store app.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will download a Visual Studio 2013 project for an app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and then sign-in to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will download a Visual Studio 2013 project for an app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and then sign-in to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A0E0E5C02&returnurl=http%3A%2F%2Fazure.microsoft.com%2Fen-us%2Fdocumentation%2Farticles%2Fmobile-services-windows-store-javascript-get-started-data%2F).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A0E0E5C02&returnurl=http%3A%2F%2Fazure.microsoft.com%2Fen-us%2Fdocumentation%2Farticles%2Fmobile-services-windows-store-javascript-get-started-data%2F).

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013, which you will use to connect your Windows Store app project to Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013, which you will use to connect your Windows Store app project to Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Download the GetStartedWithData project
trans-unit.target: Download the GetStartedWithData project

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is built on the [GetStartedWithMobileServices app][Developer Code Samples site], which is a Windows Store app project in Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is built on the [GetStartedWithMobileServices app][Developer Code Samples site], which is a Windows Store app project in Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: The UI for this app is identical to the app generated by the Mobile Services quickstart, except that added items are stored locally in memory.
trans-unit.target: The UI for this app is identical to the app generated by the Mobile Services quickstart, except that added items are stored locally in memory.

trans-unit.source: Download the JavaScript version of the GetStartedWithData sample app from the [Developer Code Samples site].
trans-unit.target: Download the JavaScript version of the GetStartedWithData sample app from the [Developer Code Samples site].

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the downloaded project, expand the **js** folder and examine the default.js file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the downloaded project, expand the **js** folder and examine the default.js file.

trans-unit.source: Notice that added **TodoItem** objects are stored in an in-memory **List** object.
trans-unit.target: Notice that added **TodoItem** objects are stored in an in-memory **List** object.

trans-unit.source: Press the **F5** key to rebuild the project and start the app.
trans-unit.target: Press the **F5** key to rebuild the project and start the app.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type some text in **Insert a TodoItem**, then click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type some text in **Insert a TodoItem**, then click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the saved text is displayed in the second column under **Query and update data**.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the saved text is displayed in the second column under **Query and update data**.

trans-unit.source: Create a new mobile service from Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Create a new mobile service from Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, expand the **services**, **mobile services**, **<your_service>** folders, open the service.js script file, and notice the new global variable, which looks like the following example:
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, expand the **services**, **mobile services**, **<your_service>** folders, open the service.js script file, and notice the new global variable, which looks like the following example:

trans-unit.source: Add a new table for data storage
trans-unit.target: Add a new table for data storage

trans-unit.source: Update the app to use the mobile service
trans-unit.target: Update the app to use the mobile service

trans-unit.source: Test the app against your new mobile service
trans-unit.target: Test the app against your new mobile service

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to run the app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to run the app.

trans-unit.source: As before, type text in **Insert a TodoItem**, and then click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: As before, type text in **Insert a TodoItem**, and then click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: This sends a new item as an insert to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This sends a new item as an insert to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In the [Management Portal], click **Mobile Services**, and then click your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In the [Management Portal], click **Mobile Services**, and then click your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Data** tab, then click **Browse**.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Data** tab, then click **Browse**.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the **TodoItem** table now contains data, with id values generated by Mobile Services, and that columns have been automatically added to the table to match the TodoItem class in the app.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the **TodoItem** table now contains data, with id values generated by Mobile Services, and that columns have been automatically added to the table to match the TodoItem class in the app.

trans-unit.source: In the app, check one of the items in the list, then go back to the Browse tab in the portal and click **Refresh**.
trans-unit.target: In the app, check one of the items in the list, then go back to the Browse tab in the portal and click **Refresh**.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the complete value has changed from **false** to **true**.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the complete value has changed from **false** to **true**.

trans-unit.source: In the default.js project file, replace the existing **RefreshTodoItems** function with the following code that filters out completed items:
trans-unit.target: In the default.js project file, replace the existing **RefreshTodoItems** function with the following code that filters out completed items:

trans-unit.source: In the app, check another one of the items in the list and then click the **Refresh** button.
trans-unit.target: In the app, check another one of the items in the list and then click the **Refresh** button.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the checked item now disappears from the list.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the checked item now disappears from the list.

trans-unit.source: Each refresh results in a round-trip to the mobile service, which now returns filtered data.
trans-unit.target: Each refresh results in a round-trip to the mobile service, which now returns filtered data.

trans-unit.source: This concludes the **Get started with data** tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This concludes the **Get started with data** tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a Windows Store app to work with data in Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a Windows Store app to work with data in Mobile Services.
